Award.AwardTitle: Spatially Resolved Optoelectronics of Strongly Correlated Nanostructures and Mott Transistors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: This research project aims to enhance our understanding of the optoelectronic properties of strongly correlated nanostructures and to develop Mott transistors incorporating vanadium dioxide nanobeams. The project is to establish a clear physical picture of energy band alignment and carrier dynamics in the insulating and metallic phases in vanadium dioxide nanobeams. The application of scanning photocurrent microscopy (SPCM) offers spatially resolved photocurrent mapping, from which local electric field distribution and charge carrier diffusion length can be extracted. Using efficient electrochemical gating, the PI also develops Mott transistors, which take advantage of the sub-100-femtosecond phase transition for information processing. SPCM is a unique tool for identifying the gate-induced metallic layer and studying the associated interfacial junction.

Non-Technical Description: Strongly correlated materials are not only fascinating test beds for studying condensed matter physics but also have high application potential for smart windows, ultrafast optical shutters, and Mott transistors, a new type of transistors with very fast operation speeds and very low energy consumption. The spatially resolved optoelectronic investigation of vanadium dioxide nanobeams can provide key information for better understanding of the metal-insulator transitions and the development of ultrafast Mott transistors. The project involves an outreach endeavor including regular seminars on nanotechnology with a focus on K-12 public schools in low-income areas of Sacramento and Davis, California. The PI incorporates the research topics on strongly correlated nanostructures into a new interdisciplinary course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project applies a spatially resolved optoelectronic method to understand and develop advanced nanomaterial based devices.  This method, based on scanning photocurrent microscopy (SPCM), involves a tightly focused laser beam which is raster scanned on nano-devices. The photocurrent is collected as a function of laser beam location. The laser beam excites charge carriers locally, which may drift or diffuse to the electrodes and lead to photocurrent. This technique allows deep understanding of electric field distribution and charge carrier transport in nano-devices, which is crucial in developing high performance devices based on nanostructures.

Using this powerful method, the PI has studied a variety of nano-devices, including lead selenide (PbSe) quantum dot (QD) thin films, lead sulfide (PbS) nanowires, silicon (Si) nanowires, indium arsenide (InAs) nanowires, and vanadium dioxide (VO2) nanowires. These nanomaterials are key components for applications in cost-effective solar cells, efficient and novel photodetector and memory devices, and transistors potentially with higher speed and lower energy consumption.  

In particular, the PI has used this spatially resolved optoelectronic technique to investigate VO2 nanowires. The sub-picosecond metal-insulator phase transition in VO2 has attracted extensive attention with potential applications in ultrafast Mott transistors, which are based on electric field induced phase transition. However, the development of VO2-based transistors lags behind, owing to inefficient and hysteretic gate modulation. The PI has achieved ambipolar doping and strong field effects free of hysteresis in single crystalline VO2 nanowires. Both the doping type of the nanowires and the band bending direction at the metal-insulator domain walls were reversibly switched by electrochemical gating, as revealed by SPCM. Furthermore, the PI's group has eliminated the hysteresis in gate sweep via a hybrid gating method, which combines the merits of liquid ionic and solid gating. The capability of efficient field effect modulation of ambipolar conduction and band alignment offers new opportunities on understanding the phase transition mechanism and enables novel electronic applications based on VO2.

The fund is used to support the education and professional training of three graduate students. Three Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) students have also worked on this project in the PI's lab and co-authored journal papers. The projects have resulted ten peer-reviewed publications. The PI has also participated in a COSMOS (California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science) program, a 4-week summer residential program for high achieving math and science 8th-12th grade high school students.
